a: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers or functions arranged in rows and columns. It is usually denoted by capital letters like \(A, B, C\) etc. Example: \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\)

q: What is the order of a matrix?
a: The order of a matrix is defined by the number of rows(m) and columns(n). If a matrix has m-rows and n-columns, it is of order \(m \times n\)
A matrix with only one row is called a Row Matrix.\ Example: \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \)
A matrix with only one column is called a Column Matrix.\ Example: \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} \)
A matrix in which all elements are zero is called a Zero Matrix.\ Example: \( O = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \)
A matrix with equal number of rows and columns is called a Square Matrix.\ Example: \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \), order = \(2 \times 2\)
A square matrix in which all non-diagonal elements are zero is called a Diagonal Matrix.\ Example: \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \)
A diagonal matrix where all diagonal elements are equal is called a Scalar Matrix.\ Example: \( A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \)
A square matrix with all diagonal elements as 1 and all other elements as 0 is called the Identity Matrix.\ Example: \( I = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \)

q: What is the transpose of a matrix?
a:
The transpose of a matrix \(A\), denoted by \(A^T\), is formed by interchanging its rows and columns.  
Example: If \(A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\), then \(A^T = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\)

A matrix \(A\) is symmetric if \(A = A^T\). It must be a square matrix.  
Example: \(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\)

A matrix \(A\) is skew-symmetric if \(A^T = -A\). Also, all diagonal elements must be zero.  
Example: \(\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ -2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

q: What is matrix addition and subtraction?
a:
Two matrices can be added or subtracted only if they have the same order.  
For matrices \(A = [a_{ij}]\) and \(B = [b_{ij}]\),  
\(A \pm B = [a_{ij} \pm b_{ij}]\)

**1. Commutative**: \(A + B = B + A\)  
**2. Associative**: \((A + B) + C = A + (B + C)\)  
**3. Additive identity**: \(A + O = A\), where \(O\) is the zero matrix  
**4. Additive inverse**: \(A + (-A) = O\)

q: What is scalar multiplication of a matrix?
a: If \(k\) is a scalar and \(A = [a_{ij}]\), then \(kA = [ka_{ij}]\). Each element of \(A\) is multiplied by \(k\).

If \(A\) is of order \(m \times n\) and \(B\) is of order \(n \times p\), then \(AB\) is defined and has order \(m \times p\).  
\((AB)_{ij} = \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{ik} b_{kj}\)

q: State the properties of matrix multiplication.
a:
**1. Associative**: \((AB)C = A(BC)\)  
**2. Distributive**: \(A(B + C) = AB + AC\)  
**3. Multiplicative identity**: \(AI = IA = A\), where \(I\) is the identity matrix  
**4. Not commutative**: \(AB \neq BA\) generally

q: Can a square matrix be both symmetric and skew-symmetric?
a: Yes, but only if all elements are zero. That is, only the zero matrix satisfies both \(A = A^T\) and \(A = -A^T\).

q: If \(A\) is skew-symmetric, what is the value of \(a_{ii}\)?
a: In a skew-symmetric matrix, diagonal elements must be zero: \(a_{ii} = 0\)
If \(A = -A^T\), then \(A + A^T = 0\)

q: Can matrix multiplication be defined if \(A\) is \(2 \times 3\) and \(B\) is \(3 \times 2\)?
a: Yes. The inner dimensions match (3), so \(AB\) is defined and will be of order \(2 \times 2\).

q: Can matrix multiplication be defined if \(A\) is \(2 \times 3\) and \(B\) is \(2 \times 3\)?
a: No. Matrix multiplication requires the number of columns of the first matrix to equal the number of rows of the second.

q: What is the product of a matrix and the zero matrix?
a: Any matrix multiplied by a zero matrix (when defined) results in a zero matrix.

q: If \(A\) is a square matrix and \(A^2 = I\), what is \(A^{-1}\)?
a: If \(A^2 = I\), then \(A^{-1} = A\), since \(AA = I\)
